title: Compliance Director Interview
Application Type: I applied online. The process took 6 weeks. I interviewed at Bon Secours
Interview Descriptions:
Gotta say this was a weird one. I received immdiate outreach from an executive recruiter expressing interest to interview, and then total silence for weeks after I responded. When I sent them a follow-up as a courtesy (in case I'd been lost in the shuffle), the recruiter responded 10 days later with an apology and offering times for an interview. I had a perfectly fine introductory interview with the senior leader, where we talked generally about the position but not really in too much detail - presumably because much of the work would be done between peers in the system.  At the end, next steps were laid out and it was fully intimated that the recruiter would be contacting me to schedule the next formal round of interviews, where we would really dig in. 

That recruiter never reached out one way or the other, even after a thank you email. The position is still posted months later.  I guess they want someone to just recruit themselves every step of the way?  Just kind of a generally unprofessional candidate experience that doesn't give off a good vibe for joining here.
Interview Questions: How does your work experience fit into this role

title: Receptionist Interview
Application Type: I interviewed at Bon Secours

title: Registered Nurse Interview

A lot was focused on my experience and what I would do in certain situations. It was a calm and inviting and everyone was nice and not intimidating.

title: Compliance Manager Interview
Application Type: I applied online. The process took 4 weeks. I interviewed at Bon Secours
Interview Descriptions: I had a 20-25 minute telephone screening with HR.  Within a couple of days, the hiring manager reached out via email to schedule a panel Zoom interview.  The panel interview lasted just over an hour, but a good 20 minutes of it consisted of one of the members berating me for wanting to leave my current position.  I am currently a licensed attorney, as were two members of the panel, and one of the attorneys was basically scolding me for trying to get a job with Bon Secour.  He kept telling me that it was a downward move and I should be applying to other law firms.  I was quite taken back because, as I mentioned before, two of these panelists were also attorneys, including the guy berating me.  It was just confusing.  The other two panelists were quite nice, but I knew I would not be getting an offer just based off of the one guy's temperamental chastising.
Interview Questions: They asked me general questions about my current work, the types of providers I work with, and difficulties I've encountered.

title: Registered Nurse Interview
Application Type: I applied online. The process took 2 weeks. I interviewed at Bon Secours (Richmond, VA) in May 2012
Interview Descriptions:
Initial step is the online application. Create a profile, save your info as you go. You can then use that completed form to apply for multiple Bon Secours positions and it is much faster. Once the app is submitted, you will be asked to complete the "survey" - it is a personality survey that determines if you would be a good fit within the company. It will ask similar questions over and over in different ways - to see if you change your answers each time, or if you are consistent. Be consistent! If you for some reason do not pass the personality survey, the HR dept will not even receive your app and you would be discarded as a candidate. So take your time with that survey!

Once you get through that exhausting process online, it's a waiting game for the call from HR. Hopefully, you will receive a call inviting you to interview with one of the managers. You will not really be given any info, other than what the position is and the name of the nurse manager, and of course the time and place for the interview.

At the interview, usually you'll meet with the nurse manager at the unit, spend some time interviewing in the office, and then spend some time taking a tour of the unit. Sometimes the nurse educator or assistant nurse manager would also sit in on the interview. Once it's over, you'll leave (hopefully with a business card!) and follow up by email to say thank you.

It totally depends on the unit and the urgency as to how long it will take to hear something. I would follow up with the HR rep after the interview, let them know how it went, that you do want the job, and to say thanks. My experience was that the following week I go a call back from HR with an offer.
Interview Questions:
The interview questions are all "behavioral" nowadays... "Tell me about a time when..."

One hard one was, "Tell me about a time when you felt angry while at work, and how was it resolved." That was hard!
